EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



This document comprises the Year 2014 Five Year Update for the Federal Risk Management Plan (Federal RMP Plan) and the California Accidental Release Prevention Program Risk Management Plan (CalARP RMP) for the Trona Facility located at 13200 Main Street in Trona, California 93562 (hereinafter referred to as the facility or the subject facility).  The Trona Facility is owned and operated by Searles Valley Minerals which is a sub-division of Nirma Limited.  Searles Valley Minerals' initial submittal for this facility was made to USEPA and to the San Bernardino County Fire Department on June 21, 1999.



The purpose of this document is to comply with the risk management planning and update requirements as set forth in the Code of Federal Regulations, Title 40, Part 68 (also known as the Federal Risk Management Plan Regulations) and the California Code of Regulations, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, Article 3, Section 2745.3 (also known as the California Accidental Release Prevention Program Risk Management Plan - CalARP RMP Regulations).  The scope of the Federal RMP and CalARP RMP includes all operations conducted at the subject facility that involve the storage, handling and/or use of chlorine and formaldehyde (i.e., chlorine and formaldehyde are the only regulated substances handled at the Trona Facility above the threshold quantity).



Searles Valley Minerals is strongly committed to the health and safety of its employees, the public and the environment.  This commitment is demonstrated by the comprehensive accidental release prevention program implemented at the Trona Facility covering aspects of operations such as design, installation, operations and maintenance, training, emergency response and other areas.  It is the Policy of Searles Valley Minerals to implement appropriate controls to prevent potential releases of regulated substances.  This is achieved through strong leadership, teamwork, effective communications, and by striving tow

ards continuous improvement in all business areas.



This commitment is consistent with the company's environmental, health and safety policy that provides that:

?    ALL facilities will be designed, operated, and managed to protect the health and safety of employees and the public;

?    ALL employees will be educated on the applicable environmental, health and safety standards and procedures;

?    Sufficient human and financial resources will be allocated to sustain these goals; and

?    Audits will be conducted regularly to verify compliance with this Policy.



These Corporate Policies also empha the importance of complying with OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard (as well as the RMP and CalARP regulations), so that ALL employees and the surrounding community will be adequately protected from potential fire, explosion, and/or toxic release hazards associated with catastrophic releases.



Searles Valley Minerals is also proud to be an active participant in the Chemical Manufacturers Association - Responsible Care Program.  As such, Searles Valley Minerals pledges to manage its business according to the principles of the Responsible Care Program.  As a member of CMA, Searles Valley Minerals is also committed to supporting a continuous effort to improve the industry's responsible management of chemicals.  



ES 1.0    DESCRIPTION OF STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED



The primary operation conducted at the Trona Facility can be categorized as NAICS Code 212391 - Potash, Soda and Borate Mineral Mining.   



Facility Location

The Searles Valley Minerals - Trona Facility is located in California's Mojave Desert, in the Searles Valley, west of Searles Lake at 13200 Main Street in Trona, California 93562.  



Facility Description

As stated previously, the Trona Facility is part of Searles Valley Minerals, which is a subdivision of Nirma Limited.  The company's Searles Valley facilities, tap into one of the richest sources of diversified minerals and c

hemicals on earth - the location contains 98 of the world's 110 known chemical elements.  Searles Valley Minerals extracts, chemically processes and ships minerals and inorganic chemical compounds to customers all over the world.  The company currently produces soda ash, sodium borates, boric acid and natural sulfate.  



A unique liquid-liquid extraction (LLX) process for manufacturing boric acid has been operated at the Facility since 1962.  An organic extractant was developed and patented for use in this process.  The boric acid process is based on the ability of the organic extractant to form a compound with certain boron compounds found in the Searles Lake brines to form a compound that has very specific properties.  



Boric acid production consists of 2 processes: liquid-liquid extraction (LLX) and evaporation-crystallization.  The liquid-liquid extraction process consists of 2 sections:

1.    A loading section where boron, sodium and potassium are extracted from the lake brine, and combined into the organic extractant used in the LLX Plant. 

2.    A stripping section where the boron, sodium and potassium are stripped from the organic extractant by contact with a dilute acidic aqueous solution to form an aqueous solution of boric acid and sodium and potassium sulfates (called the strip solution), and to regenerate the extractant for re-contact with Lake Brine.



In the evaporation-crystallization section the dilute aqueous strip solution is evaporated and the boric acid is separated from the mixed sulfates by fractional crystallization.



Description of Regulated Substance Use

The extractant is produced at the Facility by mixing a manufactured product (called P20) with kerosene in predetermined volumes according to specific procedures.  P20 is produced in the P20 Plant (at the Trona Facility) and it can be described as a 50% weight solution of specific phenolic compounds in a kerosene base.  The purpose of P20 is to provide the raw material for making the ex

on and monitoring devices;



Site Security

A chain link fence surrounds the Trona Facility.  Additionally, the Facility is protected via manned 24-hour security.  These site security provisions are intended to prevent unauthorized access to Facility areas including those areas where chlorine and formaldehyde are stored, handled or used, thus adding a level of safety for the storage of chlorine and formaldehyde at the Facility.



ES 2.0    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE SCENARIOS



The Federal RMP regulations and the CalARP RMP regulations require that at least two types of release scenarios be evaluated for their potential to impact off-site populations:



?    the worst case release; and

?    an alternative release (an accident scenario that is more credible than the worst-case release scenario).



A number of hypothetical accidental release scenarios were postulated and evaluated for the Five Year Federal RMP/CalARP RMP Update.  These scenarios were categorized into worst-case release scenarios and alternative release scenarios.  Each of these categories of hypothetical accidental release scenarios is discussed below.



CHLORINE



Worst-Case Release Scenario

In this scenario, one of the five one-ton containers of chlorine on site experiences a catastrophic failure due to an unknown event.  This scenario could be initiated by an external event (i.e., an airplane, missile or meteorite impacting the chlorine storage area where the one ton containers are located).  It is highly improbable that this scenario would be initiated by a seismic event. However, the possibility of this scenario being initiated by a seismic event cannot be completely discarded.  This scenario is considered to be extremely unlikely.  In the extremely unlikely case that this scenario occurs, up to 2,000-pounds of chlorine could be released (in the worst-case).  The release of chlorine would occur outdoors.  Thus, it was assumed that the chlorine released during the catastrophic accident form a cloud of chl

orine vapor which is free to migrate off-site.  Utilizing the BREEZE DEGADIS PLUS MODEL, the estimated vulnerable zone for this hypothetical accidental release scenario is approximately 1.7-miles.



Alternative Release Scenarios

Alternative release scenarios which are considered to be more likely to occur are those which may result in the release of anywhere from less than one-pound to up to 2000-pounds of chlorine.  These scenarios include situations such as delivery of a leaking one-ton container of chlorine to the Facility, a pinhole leak in the chlorine transfer piping (liquid or vapor transfer lines), a partial or complete failure of the chlorine transfer lines (liquid chlorine) at various points in the system (above-ground), or a partial or complete failure of the chlorine transfer lines (chlorine vapor) at various points in the system (above-ground).  In order to be conservative in the estimation of the vulnerable zone, it was assumed that 2000-pounds of chlorine gas were released during an event in which the one-inch valve on one of the containers is sheared off due to some unknown external event.  The resulting cloud of chlorine vapor was assumed to freely migrate off-site.  Utilizing the BREEZE DEGADIS PLUS MODEL, the estimated vulnerable zone for this hypothetical accidental release scenario is approximately 1.3-miles.



FORMALDEHYDE (37-PERCENT SOLUTION)



Worst-Case Release Scenario

In this scenario, the above-ground formaldehyde storage tank containing 7,000-gallons (i.e., 64,000-pounds) of 37-percent concentrated formaldehyde solution on site experiences a catastrophic failure due to an unknown event.  The failure of the tank results in spillage of formaldehyde into the containment area.  This scenario could be initiated by an external event (i.e., an airplane, missile or meteorite impacting the formaldehyde storage tank or area).  It is highly improbable that this scenario would be initiated by a seismic event.  However, the possibility of this

scenario being initiated by a seismic event cannot be completely discarded.  This scenario is considered to be extremely unlikely.  In the extremely unlikely case that this scenario occurs, up to 64,000-pounds of 37-percent concentrated formaldehyde solution could be released (in the worst-case).  It was assumed that the formaldehyde solution released during the catastrophic accident is released into the tank's containment berm forming a pool of liquid from which formaldehyde vapors are evolved.  The resulting vapor cloud was assumed to freely migrate off-site.  Utilizing USEPA's Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance Reference Tables and Equations, the estimated vulnerable zone for this hypothetical accidental release scenario is approximately 6.8-miles.



Alternative Release Scenarios

Alternative release scenarios which are considered to be more likely to occur are those which may result in the release of anywhere from less than one-pound to up to 64,000-pounds of 37-percent concentrated formaldehyde solution.  These scenarios include situations such as a pinhole leak, partial or complete failures in the formaldehyde transfer piping and/or pinhole leaks or partial failures in the formaldehyde storage tank.  In order to be conservative in the estimation of the vulnerable zone, it was assumed that 64,000-pounds of 37-percent concentrated formaldehyde solution is released during an accident involving the complete failure of a liquid transfer line from the storage tank.  In this hypothetical accidental release scenario, the transfer pump continues to transfer formaldehyde from the formaldehyde storage tank.  Eventually, the full contents of the tank (a maximum of 64,000-pounds) are spilled into the containment area surrounding the storage tank, pump and transfer lines.  Utilizing USEPA's Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance Reference Tables and Equations, the estimated vulnerable zone for this hypothetical accidental release scenario is approximately 3.2-miles.

S 3.0    FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



During the five years preceding the submittal of the Year 2014 Five Year Federal RMP/CalARP RMP Update (i.e., from June 21, 2009 through July 25, 2014), the Facility has NOT had any releases of chlorine or formaldehyde that have resulted in:

?    Onsite deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or

?    Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place.



ES 4.0    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



The Accidental Release Prevention Program at the Trona Facility consists of a series of programs, procedures and policies designed to minimize the risk of accidental releases involving chlorine and/or formaldehyde.  These programs include design and operating controls such as compliance with specified codes, the Company's health and safety program, numerous standard operating procedures, the equipment inspection and maintenance program (including a mechanical integrity and preventive maintenance program), the management of change program, pre-start-up review, fire protection and hot work permit programs, management of- and safety of- contractors, accident/incident investigation procedures, emergency response plans, the Federal RMP/CalARP RMP/OSHA PSM Program compliance auditing program, the Federal RMP/CalARP RMP/OSHA PSM Program record keeping program and a variety of personnel training programs.  Details of each of these components of the Facility's Accidental Release Prevention Program are provided in the document entitled Federal Risk Management Plan (Federal RMP), California Accidental Release Prevention Program Risk Management Plan (CalARP RMP), OSHA Process Safety Management (OSHA PSM) Program, Volume I - Prevention Program.  



There are a number of detection and monitoring devices and alarms designed to ensure the continued safe operation of the Trona Facility's P20 Process (i.e., which encompasses the storage, handling and

use of chlorine and formaldehyde).  These devices are located throughout the P20 Process Area and monitor various aspects of Operations.  



ES 5.0    EMERGENCY RESPONSE



Searles Valley Minerals recognizes that emergency preparedness, emergency planning and emergency response are an integral component of risk management.   As such, two extensive and detailed emergency response plans have been developed and implemented at the Trona Facility.  These Plans include ALL aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuation and notification of LERC/LEPD and the Public.



ALL emergency response equipment is frequently tested, inspected and serviced to ensure proper functioning.  The emergency evacuation sirens are tested every Friday at noon.  In addition, the emergency response plans are reviewed periodically and updated (as needed) to reflect pertinent changes in processes, operations and/or personnel that may require a modified emergency response.  Emergency response drills and exercises are conducted periodically to ensure rapid response and effectiveness of the emergency response team.  ALL employees and contractors are trained in the requirements of these emergency response plans.



In the unlikely event that a release does occur, Searles Valley Minerals Safety, Security, Health and Environmental (SSHE) staff and HazWOper trained emergency response personnel are at hand to control and mitigate the effects of the release.  Searles Valley Minerals coordinates its emergency response actions and efforts with several State and County Agencies.  These activities provide additional emergency response expertise to both the community and Searles Valley Minerals facilities.



ES 6.0    PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



A detailed hazard and operability study update (i.e., process hazards analysis update) was performed on ALL operations involving chlorine and formaldehyde in 2010 in order to enhance the safety of the facility and to eva

luate the potential for accidental releases.  As a result of that PHA Update, a number of recommendations were made.  ALL recommended actions have been completed and closed out.  



ES 7.0    FOR MORE INFORMATION



Searles Valley Minerals recognizes that some persons may be interested in obtaining more detailed information regarding the Five Year Federal RMP and CalARP RMP Update and various Prevention Program components not discussed herein.  Interested parties that have additional questions regarding the Trona Facility Risk Management Plan and or the Chlorine or Formaldehyde Prevention Programs, are directed to contact:
